Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: A great survey of Ancient Egypt, but with a very thematic focus on environment. Lots of primary/source texts.
Great course
How to analyze history instead of spitting it back up, Egypt was a dynamic civilization and not a static one
This is a survey course of Egyptian political and cultural history, mainly, between the Pre-Dynastic Period and the Greco-Roman Period.
I developed the ability to discuss archaeological finds, as well as a breadth of knowledge of ancient Egyptian history.
I learned a lot about the importance of analyzing archaeological finds in order to study ancient Egypt.

Strengths -- great intro to Egyptian history and analysis of themes

Weaknesses -- I felt like we went through some periods of Egyptian history too quickly and I'm still fuzzy on those eras.

Great survey course of Ancient Egypt. Having known almost nothing about the period and initially believing it constituted a static history, this course presented a fascinating look at the Ancient Egyptian world. Would absolutely recommend for those seeking a captivating history lecture!
Good course
A little bit disorganized but v interesting and informative if you keep up with the readings

This course was very interesting and covered a topic that I knew nearly nothing about. However, the 4000 year time period covered, as well as the nature of the sources, meant that it was very difficult to actually feel that I went beyond surface level engagement with any particular facet of the subject covered in the course. There was so much material over so much time that I felt that I couldn't actually learn or synthesize it to an acceptable degree.
Great lectures, but readings are often too dense.  Sections tend to vary immensely in content.
This course was very interesting and I also thought it was well-structured.
If you are a history major, interested in Ancient Egypt, or like reading ancient writing/stories, this is a great class.
Yes, great professor, great material, great class.
Yes
Yes, but I would tell them to focus more on the readings than the lectures
Yes, but you must have an interest in both history and archaeology.  This is not a purely historical course.
Yes, I would recommend this course to other students because it explores many aspects of ancient Egyptian life. It is also very interesting material.

I would highly recommend this course to another student.  Ancient Egypt is an underrepresented field in the History Department, and Professor Manning's lecture is an excellent introduction to the subject.
